item.description:
@z wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:22, topic:407394”]Is there any good reasons for that?
If not you should take that into account.[/quote]I’ve never seen a password with spaces in it. It’s fairly uncommon, it seems.

item.title: [PHP] Rainbow Table Generator
item.dc:creator: @z z
item.description:
@z wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:20, topic:407394”]Since you don’t have the length on the password, shouldn’t you have some char to tell your code that the password string is finished, and the next string is the hash. Since there can be spaces in the password (I hope you considered that), you shouldn’t assume that the string is finished when you reaches a space.

I will explain more tomorrow if you didn’t understood it. But now my brain is tired. (I should take an IQ test to measure the effect tiredness has on IQ)[/quote]I didn’t consider spaces.

Read full topic

item.title: [PHP] Rainbow Table Generator
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

Since you don’t have the length on the password, shouldn’t you have some char to tell your code that the password string is finished, and the next string is the hash. Since there can be spaces in the password (I hope you considered that), you shouldn’t assume that the string is finished when you reaches a space.

I will explain more tomorrow if you didn’t understood it. But now my brain is tired. (I should take an IQ test to measure the effect tiredness has on IQ) It didn’t btw.

Read full topic

item.title: [PHP] Rainbow Table Generator
item.dc:creator: @z z
item.description:
@z wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:18, topic:407394”]It is just one thing that might be obvious, be sure to tweak the 7z options for the best result.
You got my idea about sorting the list alphabetical after hash and not password? Because as a said it would be must faster to search.

Another thing is there is no need to add all those Fs in the start of the hashes, as you already have it in the filename. But you will have to split it up in more than 65536 .txts or else you will be huge files to decompress.
How much disc place do you have?[/quote]I’ll consider that. I have about 100GB of space right now for the 10-length character hasher, with 54M hashes stored in 5.4GB. I also am running a hasher on my main computer which is building up the 1 through 9-length character hashes with 500GB of space, only about 1GB used (1, 2, and 3-length are done, currently on 4).

54M / 94^10 = http://www3.wolframalpha.com/Calculate/MSP/MSP332619ge54e54fic16b0000069417a429720b72d?MSPStoreType=image/gif&s=21

Read full topic

item.title: [PHP] Rainbow Table Generator
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

It is just one thing that might be obvious, be sure to tweak the 7z options for the best result.
You got my idea about sorting the list alphabetical after hash and not password? Because as a said it would be must faster to search.

Another thing is there is no need to add all those Fs in the start of the hashes, as you already have it in the filename. But you will have to split it up in more than 65536 .txts or else you will be huge files to decompress.
How much disc place do you have?

Read full topic

item.title: [PHP] Rainbow Table Generator
item.dc:creator: @z z
item.description:
@z wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:16, topic:407394”][quote author=mutex_ link=topic=508678.msg3691321#msg3691321 date=1312148182]

[quote author=Bowser jr link=topic=508678.msg3691307#msg3691307 date=1312147617]

Mutex_ that is what I’m saying, and that is your advantage. But you should find a way to save space, as lots of tables take up a lot of space.

But you should organize the password after hash, not password. Since if you want to break a MD5 hash you don’t have any idea how many letters there is in the password.
[/quote]This has been the most effective method for storage I can think of. Perhaps there is an even better solution? How would putting hashes before the password benefit though?

Nothing, but it sounds like you wanted to organize it by password. What you could do is to compress your files and decompress the .txt/parts with the right password when you are decrypting.
[/quote]Could you go into more detail on this? Of course, when the finished “product” comes out, I’ll obviously want to compress the files with something like 7z or whatever.

You have the details, so long you compress with 7z and have a nice index I can’t see what you could do better.[/quote]Even the minor suggestions make the biggest data changes. Thanks.

Read full topic

item.title: [PHP] Rainbow Table Generator
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“mutex_, post:15, topic:407394”][quote author=Bowser jr link=topic=508678.msg3691307#msg3691307 date=1312147617]

[quote author=mutex_ link=topic=508678.msg3691301#msg3691301 date=1312147222]

Mutex_ that is what I’m saying, and that is your advantage. But you should find a way to save space, as lots of tables take up a lot of space.

But you should organize the password after hash, not password. Since if you want to break a MD5 hash you don’t have any idea how many letters there is in the password.
[/quote]This has been the most effective method for storage I can think of. Perhaps there is an even better solution? How would putting hashes before the password benefit though?

Nothing, but it sounds like you wanted to organize it by password. What you could do is to compress your files and decompress the .txt/parts with the right password when you are decrypting.
[/quote]Could you go into more detail on this? Of course, when the finished “product” comes out, I’ll obviously want to compress the files with something like 7z or whatever.[/quote]
You have the details, so long you compress with 7z and have a nice index I can’t see what you could do better.

Read full topic

item.title: [PHP] Rainbow Table Generator
item.dc:creator: @z z
item.description:
@z wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:14, topic:407394”][quote author=mutex_ link=topic=508678.msg3691301#msg3691301 date=1312147222]

Mutex_ that is what I’m saying, and that is your advantage. But you should find a way to save space, as lots of tables take up a lot of space.

But you should organize the password after hash, not password. Since if you want to break a MD5 hash you don’t have any idea how many letters there is in the password.
[/quote]This has been the most effective method for storage I can think of. Perhaps there is an even better solution? How would putting hashes before the password benefit though?

Nothing, but it sounds like you wanted to organize it by password. What you could do is to compress your files and decompress the .txt/parts with the right password when you are decrypting.[/quote]Could you go into more detail on this? Of course, when the finished “product” comes out, I’ll obviously want to compress the files with something like 7z or whatever.

Read full topic

item.title: [PHP] Rainbow Table Generator
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“mutex_, post:13, topic:407394”][quote author=Bowser jr link=topic=508678.msg3691258#msg3691258 date=1312144096]
Mutex_ that is what I’m saying, and that is your advantage. But you should find a way to save space, as lots of tables take up a lot of space.

But you should organize the password after hash, not password. Since if you want to break a MD5 hash you don’t have any idea how many letters there is in the password.
[/quote]This has been the most effective method for storage I can think of. Perhaps there is an even better solution? How would putting hashes before the password benefit though?[/quote]
Nothing, but it sounds like you wanted to organize it by password. What you could do is to compress your files and decompress the .txt/parts with the right password when you are decrypting.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

Mutex_ that is what I’m saying, and that is your advantage. But you should find a way to save space, as lots of tables take up a lot of space.

But you should organize the password after hash, not password. Since if you want to break a MD5 hash you don’t have any idea how many letters there is in the password.

item.title: [PHP] Rainbow Table Generator
item.dc:creator: @z z
item.description:
@z wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:10, topic:407394”][quote author=mutex_ link=topic=508678.msg3690854#msg3690854 date=1312119746]

[quote author=Bowser jr link=topic=508678.msg3690845#msg3690845 date=1312118908]

[quote author=mutex_ link=topic=508678.msg3690839#msg3690839 date=1312117932]

Why would anyone use this over existing GPU-accelerated solutions?
[/quote]Because in this context, if you have a big enough rainbow table, you will only have to search through a few dozen of the TXT files.

Johan: Searching for a password would be faster than generating it your self.
Wouldn’t searching through 4G hashes take ca 32 steps, while generating them would take 4G steps?
So this could save a lot of time.

The only problem is that this take a lot of space, and worthless if you don’t have a huge database.
[/quote]What do you mean by 4G and ca 32 steps?

4G = 4.000.000.000.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binary_search

[/quote]Ah, okay. And what about 32 ca steps?

The time it would take to find the hash. Each step reduces the search area by 50% (as long your list are sorted, and you have the correct hash in your database)[/quote]I’m assuming that as time persists, each TXT file is going to get rather large, if the character length is > 5. Possible hashes / 65536, with an imbalance of hashes stored in the TXT files. If the 10-length character rainbow table completes, it won’t take a LONG time to search for a hash; you just have to find the right file, then open the file (which could turn out to be massive in size).

Read full topic

item.title: [PHP] Rainbow Table Generator
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“mutex_, post:9, topic:407394”][quote author=Bowser jr link=topic=508678.msg3690845#msg3690845 date=1312118908]

[quote author=mutex_ link=topic=508678.msg3690839#msg3690839 date=1312117932]

[quote author=Speljohan link=topic=508678.msg3690825#msg3690825 date=1312116898]
Why would anyone use this over existing GPU-accelerated solutions?
[/quote]Because in this context, if you have a big enough rainbow table, you will only have to search through a few dozen of the TXT files.

Johan: Searching for a password would be faster than generating it your self.
Wouldn’t searching through 4G hashes take ca 32 steps, while generating them would take 4G steps?
So this could save a lot of time.

The only problem is that this take a lot of space, and worthless if you don’t have a huge database.
[/quote]What do you mean by 4G and ca 32 steps?

4G = 4.000.000.000.

en.wikipedia.org

Binary search algorithm

In computer science, binary search, also known as half-interval search, logarithmic search, or binary chop, is a search algorithm that finds the position of a target value within a sorted array. Binary search compares the target value to the middle element of the array; if they are unequal, the half in which the target cannot lie is eliminated and the search continues on the remaining half until it is successful. If the search ends with the remaining half being empty, the target is Binary search ...

[/quote]Ah, okay. And what about 32 ca steps?[/quote]
The time it would take to find the hash. Each step reduces the search area by 50% (as long your list are sorted, and you have the correct hash in your database)

Read full topic

item.title: [PHP] Rainbow Table Generator
item.dc:creator: @z z
item.description:
@z wrote:

[quote=“eczema3, post:2, topic:407394”]how long does it take[/quote]I have approximately 40M hashes for the 10-length character. It has taken me about a week, but I have been modifying it a lot. I recently fixed it up a ton and it just did 3M hashes in the past 24 hours.

It would also be worthy of mentioning that the way I have written this generator stores the table in an effective way in TXT files that allows for easy readability (has not been tested with >40M hashes, but I am progressively gaining more each day, so I will note of any slow technicalities that I run into overtime).

hashes/md5/[first 4 characters of the md5 hash].txt
So basically a hash list .txt file will look like the following, with the password being first, followed by a space, and then the hash.

0000000Cgl ffff16659c7b00a2f5ac95d4e58258a2 0000000EIB ffff28949376db0ea2131e722d8c5bf4 0000000U}} ffff09cf76e305042e8c9ff62636aecb 0000000@!- ffff0955a42c9487be874f194b65ad1f 0000000%'m ffffa38321e879091efb04a9bec440c8 0000000*D> ffffedba61b33b3859cbe9a402a57798 0000000_Sf ffffad26f16022e4d65804eeedb8fb49 0000000+)+ ffff3aaae050ddc2eeb4d16383428826 0000000]\f ffff7db176eb18daf144812b10f96084 0000000\8U ffff859d807cd2b52d28b3667982e8ec 0000000.p? ffffdebf8f68a4bbc6f8c48bec69810c 00000017Fy ffff3dcc164fe06f3349195264505620 0000001a-b ffffb351c574285161a1ee732f5fa7b4 0000001eni ffff4102611eff2de791efa40a5944f9 0000001ije ffff45f0515dd8d18cb1984c27623bbe 0000001H>% ffff3509943b891de650b6fb303c50c9 0000001Qv@ ffff88ae9c7803e09b7123d96e6336f7 0000001QUM ffffc7be374ffd19acbd06d08dc1621a 0000001X\C ffffa70da8c4bcabc1a3cb15d251d152 0000001!lm ffff505dd78879ba57e44ca1295339a7 0000001_bO ffff6b633f79fa610717d15fd9811550 0000001<{x ffff7d05353fbf73f76c3057e2ee83c8 0000001\8@ fffffc4dea3f869b4a2883a83d9a2ef2 0000002p@] ffff82472835c7277ae593e219f11e66 0000002xyZ ffff37eb067df34e28e550222f116b9e 0000002*$n ffffc6bca66c6ecd1a2c394d7e48601d 0000002]!/ ffff61b22b1d0f3dabbda7dcba7f8f69 00000037cY fffff6566b97cdcd3d76a81d0933a888 00000038CM ffffc389af5a7ccc8a2b57e705a511c1 0000003a{a ffffc8e1cdf59dcb68836952b3f03092 0000003hwY ffff1da213c4954310c229edf20494e5 0000003ivC ffffd4e179d9933cb2bb52c9e5d2f243 0000003jk8 ffffff9cc18f190c638aad56e93ae395 0000003pP{ ffff7d502dad26c1b2170de3fb5f6e1b 0000003uW9 ffff82531e9f211a86005b2519fb4748 0000003x2- ffff219dcbe29ed559ab736e83e0ffbe 0000003yGo ffffc1ad153ffb810f206572400dcf1d 0000003AMj ffffca206b7113c29d848563570ef907 0000003H1h fffff0dd08ea265de7376904aa50c2be 0000003_-a ffff81c89d41d1439e78404b26734fe7 0000003\K3 ffff6c1551da86688997965182097a22 0000003.YR ffff3c5008ec076f6fc7c80112dbbd7c 0000004d&Y ffffe99e31290f71bfb389cc1877778e 0000004gfR ffffd88a4201757d1d9308551e86c224

Because the first four characters of the TXT can each contain only 16 possible characters, we represent this as 16^4 files, which is 65,536 total txt files. Even when trying to work on a 25-length character generated table, you won’t run into any slowness after generating the same amount of hashes as the 10-length character generated table because you will be working with the same amount of files with 15 additional bytes per password (hashes are the same length).

Read full topic

item.description:
@eczema3 wrote:

how long does it take

Read full topic

item.title: [PHP] Rainbow Table Generator
item.dc:creator: @z z
item.description:
@z wrote:

Thoughts? Special thanks to super_ for inspiration!!![code]<?php
define(‘DS’,DIRECTORY_SEPARATOR);
error_reporting(E_ALL);
$rainbow_table_root = ‘D:\hasher\’;
$hashes_location = ‘D:\hasher\hashes\’;

if(!is_dir($rainbow_table_root))
mkdir($rainbow_table_root) or die(‘Failed to create rainbow table root directory.’);

if(!is_dir($hashes_location))
mkdir($hashes_location) or die(‘Failed to create hashes location.’);

ob_start();
$characters = array();
foreach(range(0,9) as $number)
$characters[] = $number;
foreach(range(‘a’,‘z’) as $letter)
$characters[] = $letter;
foreach(range(‘A’,‘Z’) as $capital_letter)
$characters[] = $capital_letter;
foreach(array(’!’,’@’,’#’,’$’,’%’,’^’,’&’,’*’,’(’,’)’,’_’,’+’,’{’,’}’,’|’,’:’,’"’,’<’,’>’,’?’,’-’,’=’,’[’,’]’,’\’,’;’,’’’,’,’,’.’,’/’) as $character)
$characters[] = $character;

echo count($characters).’ character’.(count($characters) == 1 ? ‘’ : ‘s’).’ loaded.’."\n";

$md5_nodupes = false;
$sha1_nodupes = false;
$md5_nodupes_count = 0;
$sha1_nodupes_count = 0;
$wrote_count = false;

function hasher($length,$current_position,$current_string)
{
global $rainbow_table_root,$hashes_location,$characters,$md5_nodupes,$sha1_nodupes,$md5_nodupes_count,$sha1_nodupes_count,$wrote_count;
if($length == $current_position)
{
$skip_md5 = $skip_sha1 = $written = false;

	$passwd = $current_string;

	$md5 = md5($passwd);
	$sha1 = sha1($passwd);

	if(!is_dir($hashes_location.DS.$length))
		mkdir($hashes_location.DS.$length) or die('Failed to create '.$hashes_location.DS.$length);
	if(!is_dir($hashes_location.DS.$length.DS.'md5'))
		mkdir($hashes_location.DS.$length.DS.'md5') or die('Failed to create '.$hashes_location.DS.$length.DS.'md5');
	if(!is_dir($hashes_location.DS.$length.DS.'sha1'))
		mkdir($hashes_location.DS.$length.DS.'sha1') or die('Failed to create '.$hashes_location.DS.$length.DS.'sha1');

	$filename = $hashes_location.DS.$length.DS.'md5'.DS.substr($md5,0,4).'.txt';
	$pointer = fopen($filename,'a+');
	if($md5_nodupes === false)
	{
		$contents = fread($pointer,filesize($filename));
		if(!strpos($contents,$md5)) // to prevent dupes
		{
			if($md5_nodupes_count > 5)
				$md5_nodupes = true;
			$md5_nodupes_count++;
			$written = fwrite($pointer,$passwd.' '.$md5."\n");
		}
		else
			$skip_md5 = true;
	}
	else
		$written = fwrite($pointer,$passwd.' '.$md5."\n");
	fclose($pointer);

	$filename = $hashes_location.DS.$length.DS.'sha1'.DS.substr($sha1,0,4).'.txt';
	$pointer = fopen($filename,'a+');
	if($sha1_nodupes === false)
	{
		$contents = fread($pointer,filesize($filename));
		if(!strpos($contents,$sha1)) // to prevent dupes
		{
			if($sha1_nodupes_count > 5)
				$sha1_nodupes = true;
			$sha1_nodupes_count++;
			$written = fwrite($pointer,$passwd.' '.$sha1."\n");
		}
		else
			$skip_sha1 = true;
	}
	else
		$written = fwrite($pointer,$passwd.' '.$sha1."\n");
	fclose($pointer);

	if(time() % 10 == 0 && $wrote_count === false) // update this less often
	{
		$pointer = fopen($rainbow_table_root.'count.txt','w');
		$wrote_count = fwrite($pointer,$count);
		fclose($pointer);
	}
	elseif(time() % 10 == 0)
		$wrote_count = true;
	else
		$wrote_count = false;

	if($written !== false)
		echo $passwd."\n"; // reduce printing to a very minimal otherwise the hashing goes slower...
	else
		echo $passwd." skip\n";
	ob_flush();
}
else
	for($index = 0; $index < count($characters); $index++)
		hasher($length,$current_position + 1,$current_string.$characters[$index]);

}

for($length = 0; $length < 10; $length++)
hasher($length,0,’’);
?>[/code]

Read full topic
